Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: American Innovations in an Age of Discovery: Teaching Science and Engineering through 3D-printed Historical Reconstructions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Advanced manufacturing technologies, such as 3D printing, are transforming design and several fields of engineering. This innovative project will use 3D technology to help students learn about science and engineering through the history of inventions in the United States. As part of science and engineering classes, middle and high-school students will use 3D printing technology to recreate historically significant inventions, using digitized versions from the Smithsonian Institution (e.g., the Wright brothers' airplane - http://3d.si.edu). The project will create modules that will connect these significant inventions from the past with contemporary technologies, science, and engineering. Student teamwork will help participants understand the collaborative process of invention. The project will develop supporting materials for middle school science and engineering teachers. This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM).

The module development will address calls in recent national reports and standards for the integration of engineering in science teaching and learning. The research questions and data collection/analysis will examine how the modules impact student knowledge of the concepts and if teachers can successfully implement them in classrooms. Data to be collected include students' work on the modules, interviews and focus groups with students, interviews with teachers, and classroom observation. Using comparison classrooms, the study will also use pre-tests and post-tests of students' content knowledge to understand the impact of the modules in the treatment classrooms on students' knowledge of science and engineering. The goal will be to document the impact of the modules on students' learning in science and engineering courses and to understand how historical inventions can be used to engage students in how scientific and engineering innovation happen. The implementation will include school districts with diverse populations of students in two states, providing a range of test sites for the materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The American Innovations in an Age of Discovery initiative is a collaboration among the Make to Learn Laboratory at the University of Virginia, the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History, the Joseph Henry Project for Historical Reconstruction at Princeton, Midlands Technical College, and the Laboratory School for Advanced Manufacturing in the Charlottesville City Schools. A series of Make to Learn Invention Kits enable students to use school makerspaces to reconstruct working models of transformational inventions that changed the world. The goal for the students is not to create exact physical replicas of inventions, but to reinterpret and reinvent mechanisms using modern technologies.

Selected inventions such as the telegraph, the telephone, and early electric motors were digitized and made available on the Smithsonian X 3D web site (3d.si.edu/invention):

  1. Telegraph Invention Kit
      a. Telegraph Key
      b. Telegraph Relay
      c. Telegraph Sounder

 2. Telephone Invention Kit
     a. Microphone
     b. Amplifier
     c. Speaker

  3. Electric Motor Invention Kit
      a. Rotary Motor
      b. Linear Motor
      c. Stepper Motor

Each kit has a number of subcomponents and extensions. For example, Make to Learn Invention Kits were developed for three types of motors in the electric motor sequence:  (a) the Davenport Rotary motor, (b) the Charles Page Solenoid motor, and (c) a contemporary linear motor based on a twentieth-century design.

In addition to 3D scans of the original artifact in the Smithsonian collections, Invention Kits include 3D-printer files that permit students to download and print components. Animations depict operation of the invention and its moving parts. Editable computer-assisted design (CAD) files enable students to modify designs to create their own inventions. These CAD files are freely available for educational use by teachers and students. The Invention Kits also provide primary source documents such as patent descriptions, associated pedagogical materials and teacher guides.

Curators at the National Museum of American History ascribe the current maker movement to a tradition that can be traced to the founding of the nation. Brooke Hindle, former director of the National Museum of American History, notes enthusiasm for mechanization and invention was incorporated at an early stage into the vision of the nation. Based on his research as director of the National Museum of American History, Hindle concluded that invention through emulation was a key pedagogical mechanism responsible for this success. Apprentices learned by first copying the work of master craftsmen, incorporating concepts learned into their own subsequent work.

This method has been successfully implemented at Princeton University through the course, Engineering in the Modern World. This method has also been incorporated into the Machine Tool program at Midlands Technical College. A key outcome of the current initiative was successful extension of this method to middle school science and engineering classes through Make to Learn Invention Kits. The Invention Kits were piloted in schools in Virginia, Pennsylvania, North Carolina, Texas, and Maine. The Invention Kits were then disseminated nationally through the Smithsonian's X 3D web site. The Telegraph Invention Kit was also adapted for use as an interactive exhibit in the Smithsonian?s Spark!Lab, which has 500 to 1,000 visitors per day.

Other outcomes include seven doctoral theses, 25 peer-reviewed journal articles, and three book chapters published in the course of the initiative. This work has thus far been disseminated through more than 50 conference presentations and workshops. The following publications provide an overview of the process of developing and implementing Invention Kits:

  • Bull, G., Garofalo, J., Littman, M., Sherman, R., Hoffman, M., Grant, M. M., & Grier, A. (2017). Make to learn: invention through emulation.  Smart Learning Environments. 
  • Bull, G., Garofalo, J., Littman, M. & Hoffman, M. (2018). The Make to Learn Electric Motor Design Sequence.  International Journal of Designs for Learning. 

The Make to Learn Invention Kits developed through this initiative also served as the foundation for a subsequent NSF-funded project, Computational Thinking in Industrial Automation (Strategies: NSF STEM-C DRL-1842342; PI G. Bull, 1/1/19 ? 12 /31/21).
